required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Health Effects of Milk Proteins in Elderly Subjects
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Milk Proteins on Body Composition, Muscle Strength, Inflammation and Bone Health in Elderly Subjects

collaborator.agency: Oslo and Akershus University College of Applied Sciences

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of the present study is to investigate effects of milk on body composition and muscle strength, inflammation, appetite, DNA damage/repair and PBMC whole genome transcriptomics in elderly subjects.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Change in muscle mass, strength and performance
primary_outcome.time_frame: Measured at baseline and after 12 weeks (end-of-study visit)
primary_outcome.description: Change in muscle is mass measured by DXA. Muscle strength and performance are measured by several physical tests such as repeated chair stands, handgrip strength, step stair test and strength in legs and torso and gait speed and are considered as the clinical relevant outcomes.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in levels of inflammatory markers
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured at baseline and after 12 weeks (end-of-study visit)
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in levels of inflammatory markers in circulation and at PBMC gene Expression Level such as i.e. CRP, IL-6, TNFa, IL-8, IL-18, ICAM, VCAM.

other_outcome.measure: Effect on PBMC whole genome transcriptomics
other_outcome.time_frame: Measured at baseline and after 12 weeks (end-of-study visit)
other_outcome.description: Measurement of PBMC Whole genome transcriptomics will be performed.

other_outcome.measure: Changes in body composition (including bone mineral density)
other_outcome.time_frame: Measured at baseline and after 12 weeks (end-of-study visit)
other_outcome.description: Changes in body composition are measured by DXA.

other_outcome.measure: Changes in the level of appetite regulatory hormones
other_outcome.time_frame: Measured at baseline and after 12 weeks (end-of-study visit)
other_outcome.description: Changes in the level of appetite regulatory hormones such as i.e. adiponectin, glucagon-like protein (GLP-1), gastric inhibitory polypeptide (GIP), ghrelin, Peptide YY (PYY) and cholecystokinin (CCK)

other_outcome.measure: Changes in the Lymphocyte DNA damage and repair system
other_outcome.time_frame: Measured at baseline and after 12 weeks (end-of-study visit)
other_outcome.description: Changes will be measured using Whole blood and PBMC.

intervention.description: 4 dl milk will be consumed daily with breakfast and supper for 12 weeks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- ≥ 70 years of age
- reduced gait speed or
- reduced "five times sit to stand test" or
- reduced "timed step stair test " or
- reduced grip strength
- Stable body weight (last 3 months)
- Mini Nutritional Assessment (MNA®) score ≥ 17
- Mini-mental status (MMSE-NR) score: ≥ 24
- Willing to participate according to the protocol
Exclusion Criteria:
- Allergy/intolerance to milk/dairy products
- High intake of milk and yoghurt
- Physical active subjects
- Known diabetes type I or II, or HbA1c ≥ 6,5%
- Recent events of acute cardiovascular disease including stroke
- Rapidly evolving diseases (active malignancy) or history of cancer (malignant tumors) last 3 years.
- Severe inflammation-related diseases such as e.g. Crohn disease and arthritis
- Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
- Increased blood pressure
- High intake of alcohol
- Reduced kidney function (GFR < 45 ml/min)
- Increased hsCRP, ASAT, ALAT
- Increased or suppressed TSH
- Hormone therapy
- Systemic use of glucocorticosteroids (anti-inflammatory steroid hormones). Use of spray and inhalator use is not exclusion.
- Disability preventing physical tests
- Using medications known to affect protein metabolism

overall_official.affiliation: Institute of Basic Medical Sciences, Faculty of medicine, University of Oslo
